review.title: An MLP based Approach for Recognition of Handwritten `Bangla' Numerals
review.abstract: The work presented here involves the design of a Multi Layer Perceptron (MLP) based pattern classifier for recognition of handwritten Bangla digits using a 76 element feature vector. Bangla is the second most popular script and language in the Indian subcontinent and the fifth most popular language in the world. The feature set developed for representing handwritten Bangla numerals here includes 24 shadow features, 16 centroid features and 36 longest-run features. On experimentation with a database of 6000 samples, the technique yields an average recognition rate of 96.67% evaluated after three-fold cross validation of results. It is useful for applications related to OCR of handwritten Bangla Digit and can also be extended to include OCR of handwritten characters of Bangla alphabet.

sections.heading: 4 Results and Discussion
sections.text: MLP classifiers require training with marked samples before they are put into operation as pattern classifiers. Following the training, it is tested whether an MLP classifier can generalize from test data what it has learned from training data. To prepare the training and test sets of samples, a database of 6,000 Bangla digits is created by collecting optically scanned, handwritten samples with 10-digit symbols of 600 people of different ages and genders each. A training set of 4,000 samples and a test set of 2,000 samples is then created. In total, three such pairs of training and test sets are created with the original database for cross-validating the results at the time of the experiment. All samples are scaled to 32x32 pix32 pixel images and then converted into binary images by threshold values. For the present work, a single layer of MLP is formed, i.e. an MLP with a hidden layer of 4000 training samples and hidden samples.

sections.text: Curves showing a variation in the detection performance of the MLP, for the test samples of the three groups, the hidden intelligence is observed, with the number of neurons in the hidden layer of the MLP increasing so that it can show the optimal detection performance on the test group. Detection performance of the MLP for group # 2, as observed from the curve in Figure # 8, initially increases when the number of neurons in the hidden layer of the MLP is increased and falls after the same limits are exceeded, reflecting the fact that the learning and generalization capabilities of the MLP improve as the number of neurons in its hidden layer increases to certain limits, and any further increase of neurons in the hidden layer.
